segments.text: about the low level of support when, in these restricted times, there's vastly more money available than the old bailing wire and sealing wax days at Lowell.
Yeah.

I mean, when I went to Lowell, I mean, typical salary level, I don't remember what I was paid, but it's less than we pay a graduate student assistant coming in now who's supposedly spending most of his time just studying.

so uh yeah and those of us who've held positions for a long time i've been 30 years now or going on 30 years at university of arizona our salaries have fallen behind uh so it's called the compression effect uh considerably behind uh new appointees so it's only because well i've been in i mean my house is paid for so i don't have to pay a big mortgage and so in a sense i feel that i'm
I can afford to draw this salary, but I think there's too much focus and too much attention on short-term science, new people coming in.
They have to move very rapidly.
You've got to publish results very quickly, pick up, I think, many, many superficial things.
In-depth science has suffered.
And I don't think there's a proper balance of support for deeper studies, more controversial studies.
So I don't have a lot of sympathy for the complaints of many of the younger scientists.
I don't think that's the central problem that we face in astronomy.
I think we're overpopulated with astronomy, and I think we're driven by to produce results quickly.
I'm an old-fashioned astronomer who believes that the way Mount Wilson and places like that worked years ago, where you could study a problem, think about it, and publish a definitive analysis.
I mean, the kind of work that Merrill did and Joy and so on, those I think, that's the way I still think there's room for that kind of support in astronomy.
And we see very little of it.
I want to ask you one general, one specific question.
The specific one is, what's the reaction of people that you meet when they find out you're an astronomer?
Good, bad, and different surprises?
I think the general public is well attuned to astronomy.
And I don't think we've ever had a problem

selling astronomy fundamentally, gee, there's a lot of misunderstanding of what astronomy is, but I think there's an automatic, fairly positive reaction to astronomy because, gee, yeah, I mean, it's telling us what's out there, and there's a natural interest in that.
I don't think there's any problem at that level with getting an initial positive reaction to astronomy.
It's at the next level when you start asking for money or explaining how expensive it is to run this business that people get a little puzzled.
And well, even then, well, just if you give us the proper information or proper justification, maybe we're not fundamentally objecting to it.
I think we have more problem internally in astronomy in the way we've decided to allocate our resources.
And I can be perfectly honest in making one of the strong comparisons I'm sure has been made many times between the way
say NRAO and NOAO are run.
NRAO is a real service institution that really helps astronomers with individual ideas.
And it doesn't get any complaints either.
Right.
It's a great institution.
And the controversy that revolves around NOAO, I'm not an authority on that, but it's an entirely different situation.
But you live in Tucson, right?
That's the way things are funded now.
I mean, if you want to do a research program or do an observing program or apply for a grant, you have got to say exactly what you're going to do and exactly what you're going to find.
But of course, in the kind of work that I do, you can't do that.
I mean, we're investigating a phenomena that we don't understand.
And historically, that's where the major advances in science have come.
I think if you look at the history of science,
and I'm no authority on history of science like you are, Ron, but... Not yet.
It's not out of these big institutions, necessarily, that the real advances come, because the proposals are reviewed in such microscopic detail that there really isn't any question left.
It's just refining the next significant figure or something like that.
It's only the tenured professors with some far-out idea or people that are willing to

take a big risk they can investigate the unknown and take on an observing program or do an observing program where they don't know what they're gonna find because you can't write that kind of proposal nobody's gonna fund it nobody's gonna support it Galileo wouldn't stand a chance today no I mean to build a telescope I mean everybody knew what you're gonna see when you looked at Jupiter or something
It wasn't going to have moon circling around it.
There was nothing unknown out there.
So you can't write that kind of proposal.
And I think that's exactly the kind of proposal that we need.
The same is true for publication.
When you send a paper in to the Astrophysical Journal or to a main journal, I've had plenty of experience with this, where you try to develop a new idea.
or suggest a new interpretation.
If it's inconsistent with what is, quote, presently known or presently being modeled, you're going to meet immense resistance.
And to introduce a new or a different idea is very, very difficult.
You can't do it.
I can't work with graduate students or people that future depend upon their being able to get a job
that having connection with TIFF is not wise.

I can do it because I've got tenure, because I've got security, and because my salary is big enough that my expenses aren't that big, I can afford to go to the AAS meeting and have my own home computer and a few computer programs so I can generate poster papers, I can write papers.
I may even end up having to pick up some of my publication charges.
There aren't many people in a position to do that.
There's something wrong with the way science is being supported and funded.
I don't think we need a lot of money for this, but I think there ought to be means of handling new ideas.
We ought to somehow try to create a means of supporting new ideas based upon just the experience with the people.
People know that I do
good observational work.
There ought to be a means of supporting these kinds of things.
I'm not speaking specifically for myself, but I know there are a lot of people out there.
I assume this criticism applies to NSF and NASA together in that they are both unwilling to take any chances whatsoever.
Right.
I mean, Jocelyn Gill's office, for example, and this was an aspect of the older NASA,
was willing to take this kind of risk in the Lunar Programs Lab and Marshall Space Flight Center.
They said, yeah.
I mean, sure, they were vested interest in this.
But on the other hand, there were no strings attached to the support.
They say, go out and build some good programs that we can fly.
Sure, they were interested.
They wanted programs developed.
But they gave the support to people who were motivated to try something new.
We don't see much of that now.
and this collecting of everybody into teams to do a specific job, there's no flexibility.
There's no ability of the scientists to develop a completely new idea.
We've seen these plateaus in the history of science frequently.
Everything is known, and all we've got to do is work out the next details.
We aren't any closer to the final answers than we were
We're in the 18th century, but a lot of people think we are.
